title: Hopefully the last Hunger Games movie
text: Not being an avid reader it's quite unusual for me to see a movie franchise having already read the books. It isn't unusual for me to read the book(s) after watching the film(s), but for some reason there's always a worry that the movie isn't going to live up to the book when you've read the book. I have to confess that this is very much the way I felt about the Hunger Games movies.The splitting up of the Mockingjay really smacks of the movie producers earning more revenue rather than any artistic reason. To be fair to the producers it's mission accomplished as the combined box office for the 2 Mockingjay movies will be well in excess of the Catching Fire movie.As for the movie itself it is very hard to feel much empathy with Katniss(Lawrence), Peeta(Hutcherson) or Gale(Hemsworth) as they take on the might of President Snow. Some of the set pieces are reminiscent of the Mission Impossible franchise scenes which are just dumb and implausible. Personally I hope there isn't a prequel for whilst there's potential for it to be good, there's much more potential for it to be a stinker!

title: INTENSE AS HELL!
text: Packed with unrelenting action & truthful in the aftermath & political motives of war, Mockingjay Part 2 is a more than satisfying end to the Hunger Games saga.The storyline greatly benefits from staying true to the book, but it is Frank Lawrence's directing that really brought Suzanne Collin's bleak & unforgiving themes, to life. Under Frank's helm, the horrors of the war against the capital is in full display and sincerely felt. His portrayal is honest & unnerved in showcasing the deadliest tactics and the body count that ensues. As a result, stakes are higher and well perceived, action is INTENSE AS HELL which is the film's highlight & outcomes are shocking to say the least. And this is from someone who read the book!As for the acting, props to ALL the supporting characters. Despite being relegated to the sidelines, their brief appearances deliver poignant scenes. It is only Jennifer Lawrence's acting that I reman aloof as it is too "cinematic" & less natural for my taste. Nevertheless, we have her to thank for an iconic Katniss.Overall, Frank Lawrence's adaptation adds a resounding closure to the one of the best dystopian film franchises we have today. It is a great watch for both hardcore fans and casual movie goers looking for a film with substance.

title: Part meh, part decent ending to the series
text: Released in 2015, "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2" is the fourth and final part in the franchise based on Suzanne Collins' popular books. A new nation, Panem, exists in post-apocalyptic North America where Capitol is the seat of Panem's wealthy, eccentric populace and cruel totalitarian government led by the pompous President Snow (Donald Sutherland). The war of Panem escalates and so Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), the reluctant leader of the rebellion, takes her team consisting of Gale (Liam Hemsworth), Cressida (Natalie Dormer) and others to Capitol in hopes of assassinating Snow and returning peace to Panem. In the meantime she tries to return Peeta (Josh Hutcherson) to his normal state. Other characters include President Coin (Julianne Moore) and her associates (Philip Seymour Hoffman, Jeffrey Wright and Mahershala Ali). Woody Harrelson, Jena Malone, Patina Miller and Elizabeth Banks are also on hand.I'm not a huge fan of The Hunger Games films, but I'll watch 'em (mainly 'cause my wife likes 'em). I gave the first one a 7/10 and the next two devolved in value. This final sequel is a natural extension, but like the other films there's not a lot of action and the drama isn't very compelling, but it's okay. It comes across as drama for teenage girls, which shouldn't be surprising since that's the target audience of the books. Nevertheless, Jennifer is a likable, fair protagonist and I appreciate the realistic air and overall ambiance, as well as the entire dystopian concept. The movie (and series) just needed more oomph and depth. However, I salute Katniss' decision to do what she had to do to Hilarity at the end. Oh, wait, that wasn't Hilarity.The first and third films were highlighted by the great closing songs "Abraham's Daughter" by Arcade Fire and "Yellow Flicker Beat" by Lorde, but the second and fourth films lack such a highlight.The film is overlong at 137 minutes and was shot in Georgia, USA, Germany and France.GRADE: C+ (5.5/10 Stars)

title: No point to split 2 films when it can be one
text: Comparing the success of the first two Hunger Games films, the mocking jay part 1 is a different pace and way out of the film success equation. It's like suddenly the audiences are watching a different cinematic universe when they are all adapted into the first two. As such, part 1 is boring and slow, but as we all get to see part 2, we have the patience to forgive that it takes time to build up the ground for the story of part 2 the final. However, it turns out that's not the case.Part 2 is even boring and the pace is strange. Sometimes it is too slow in the drama part that you are like watching Steven Spielberg's Lincoln. And the action part is too short to create a tension like the first two. What's the success of the first two Hunger Games, are the anxiety that the characters may got kill in every minutes and the contrast of the high glamorous society with the middle age look sections. In this film, you cannot see these elements going on. This in- consistence makes the audiences draw back from the film with lots of disappointments. The story line is fine but the directing just ruins the whole franchise.Unlike the Harry Potter and Twilights that has a point to split the ending into the two films, this mocking jay is absolute a failing in doing so.

title: Disappointing Third (4th?) Act
text: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 picks up immediately where Part 1 leaves off: Peeta has just been returned to District 13, and the districts are preparing their assault on the malevolent Capitol. Francis Lawrence returned to direct this fourth and final movie based on the popular young adult novels by Suzanne Collins. Mockingjay Part 2 continues the disappointing direction of the series, focusing on politics and propaganda, rather than on the visceral action and interesting characters that made the first two films so enjoyable.Some quick thoughts about Part 1 before I begin discussing Part 2 in further detail: I don't believe this novel should have been split into two films. The Mockingjay book is just as long as the first two novels in the series, and Catching Fire, in particular, did a great job of adapting the novel into only one film. But hey, it's all about the $$$.Mockingjay Part 2 continues the uninteresting storyline in which District 13 is attempting to portray Katniss Everdeen (played by Jennifer Lawrence) as the symbol of the rebellion. Katniss is bottled up for a majority of Part 1 and Part 2, acting in propaganda videos and being babysat by those around her. She rarely gets to use her bow and arrow to actually fight for herself. Katniss doesn't need her bow and arrow in order to be defined as a strong character, but the fact that she doesn't have a huge role in the actual rebellion is a huge waste of her potential.Mockingjay Part 2 is also very slow. There is nearly an hour before there is any action, and there are only a few major action sequences in the whole film. Yes, the first two films are largely without action until their respective Hunger Games, but at least in those films you were being introduced to a new world and interesting characters, not watching an advertising campaign. However, there is one action sequence in a sewer that I thought was exciting, and suspenseful.There are no bad performances in Mockingjay Part 2. Jennifer Lawrence is great as Katniss, and the supporting performances are all fine. Josh Hutcherson plays Peeta, and while he does a fine job with what he's given, he is limited by the fact that his character is brainwashed throughout. This is disappointing considering I always found him to be one of the more interesting characters in the world of Panem.Without any spoilers, the film's ending is very anticlimactic and feels very forced. The ending dampens the events of the previous films and really made me wonder, "It all lead to THIS?"Mockingjay Part 1 started the negative turn in momentum in the series, and Part 2 could never get that train back (to District 12) on track. *cue Rue's whistle*If you liked this review, check out more of my reviews over at www.watsonmoviereviews.com

title: The best in the franchise

title: Could be better
text: A big part of people have read the The Hunger Games trilogy and were interested in movies based on this novel. I am one of those people. But, to be honest, the film disappointed me... I've been expecting something better. No, I haven't wasted my time, but I didn't enjoy this creation. The book reader sinks in action between the first 10 pages, but in film, you are watching the first 30 minutes and still, nothing's happening. I had started to get bored. The weakest part of script is that... okay, there are a lot of unexpected twists and moments, but this is the backbone of film, the film is based on this. And it's impossible to watch this movie for the second time, because there will be nothing fresh. The idea is quite original, but quite flat as well. The only thing that I cannot complain about is visual effects - that's majestic. So. The film is better than the big part of action movies. At least I am trying to believe this statement. You will enjoy dramatic plot twists, but I will not watch this for the second time, because there will be no drama, intriguing parts or something like that left. I recommend this for easy and light Friday evening with your friends. Nothing more.

title: This Story Just Went Way Off Course
text: Okay, so for starters, I've not read the books at all. I only got into "The Hunger Games" series with the first movie, which I thought was great. The second movie was fine, the third one took me a second viewing to really appreciate, but after seeing it again I was into the direction that everything seemed to be heading.And then last night I saw "Mockingjay Part 2", and I have to say that the whole series just ended quite oddly. There was plot twist after plot twist--so much so that it was obvious that the author was just adding in those twists as a way to shock the audience and to keep things fresh, as opposed to telling a genuinely entertaining and engaging story.I will say that the film was extremely well made. All of the things that I normally am quite critical of that tend to make or break a movie for me, this movie did well: the pacing of the film, the acting, the dialogue and the way the film told the story it set out to tell were all exemplary. And, sure, even though I disliked the story that was told, there were nevertheless moments when that story was interesting--Katniss's eventual confrontation with the film's twin antagonists, for example.Still, the story just didn't do it for me. It would be hard to say much more without giving it all away in a spoiler, but just note that this movie doesn't lead toward a heroic resolution in the sense that one might expect. There is a great sense of unease at the film's conclusion. This wasn't the story I thought I was paying for or wanted to see.The last thing I'll note is that while the movie is well made, there is also a sense in which the film comes across as a Peter Jackson movie (LOTR/The Hobbit films), which tend to be criticized as being heavy on computer graphics that seem to be made for video game prototypes. At several points it seemed quite obvious that the main point of the film was to set up its video game rendition, as opposed to advancing the film's plot.All that said, I have to go for 5/10 stars on this one. Its well made and somewhat entertaining, but what it gets right in the storytelling department it fails in the story writing aspect.

title: PERFECT ENDING
text: This movie. When I first heard that mockingjay was going to have 2 parts, I was devestated because I thought it was just not needed and thought everything would perfectly fit into a one movie, to make the hunger games the perfect trilogy. But the way they made this movie as the final one so perfect, I just want to give them an Oscar. The music, the plot, the acting... Everything is so perfect. title: "Turn your weapons to Snow!"
text: Katniss Everdeen: "Tonight, turn your weapons to the Capitol!".The story in Mockingjay Part 2 is Katniss fully embracing her role as the face of the district revolution in the "Mockingjay" she leads an all-out assault on the capital to bring down President Snow and his autocratic rule once and for all.After the dull filler that was Mockingjay Part 1, I mean splitting movies into two parts isn't a great idea with some book adaption movies that don't need it, because the books themselves were not long and flowed together nicely. And yes Harry Potter did the splitting movies into two because well, the book itself was freaking huge, so huge that a little toddler can reach the top shelf by standing on the freaking book. It's completely pointless and now every book adaptation movie is doing it just to cash in more money.I didn't like Mockingjay Part 1 that much. Nothing interesting was developed in that movie and part 1 was nothing but a set up to the next movie, which you should never do, because when you do a marathon of all of the movies, part 1 is the one that you want to skip. That's what Part 1 was 'a set up' and it doesn't stand on it's own as film (In my opinion). But all that a side, I sawed Mockingjay Part 2 a few days ago and it wasn't that great. It was way better than Part 1 when comes to something happening, but that's not saying much, because while I was watching the movie I had the same uneasy feel that Part 1 gave me and not in a good way. It isn't a bad movie, but it wasn't great.The one major positive that I can give that was all throughout The Hunger Games franchise was Jennifer Lawrence. She has so much to do here and really makes her character shine in this movie. She once again dose a great performance that wasn't over acting or being too dramatic, but it was simple and locked down. She was without a doubt the best part of this movie.This is a very dark and grim movie with no comic relief from the other characters, and these no messing around here and that element in the movie dose work...sometimes. These many scenes in this movie that was overly sad and so dramatic, to the point that I said to myself "Oh my lord, this movie is so miserable and grim". I know a finale like this isn't going to end quietly and it worked sometimes, but sometimes it overly did it.This is Philip Seymour Hoffman's last movie and I think the movie did justice for his character in a respectful way due to the actors passing. I know it was hard for the cast to deal with Hoffman's death, since he's character had a major scene in this movie that he never got a chance to film due to his death. I thought the movie did great job of working around it respectfully. R.I.P Philip Seymour Hoffman.Now for the problems: The first half of this movie and the last is so freaking slow with it's pacing, to the point that it was basically killing the spirit of this movie with the lack of energy. The movie never made me feel like the stakes were high as it felt too easy. There was never a moment that made me feel like I was on the edge of my seat or biting my nails worried for what's going, because as I said before the stakes never felt high to me. That's really disappointing and I had so much high hopes for this movie to be an intense finale with a satisfying ending...well I got some of that, but not the satisfying or intense part.Was the ending satisfying? well, it was fine ending, but not the best as the movie didn't know how to end. The endings were dragged out.Overall Mockingjay Part 2 will satisfy some fans of the franchise. I do think it's better Part 1 as I felt like a lot of things were happening. Unfortunately this movie dose have the same problems that Part 1 had with it's pacing and it's lack of energy. I didn't think this movie was great and I know for a fact that five years from now I will completely forget about this movie.

title: The Best Hunger Games Movie
text: Truly the best Hunger Games movie . This movie knows exactly how to balance drama and battle at the same time. It doesn't feel weighted, nor boring.

title: Unnecessary & Draggy Zombie-Wanna-Be Movie
text: I just don't understand why they did it like this. It's like nothing is here, nothing, nothing but a terrible unbearable torture 80% of the movie. title: No Mocking but Yay! Splendid until they end it
text: *This review may contain spoilers, it depends on how imaginative you are, so be warned and do not take the risk because you really need to see this for yourself!*I'm still listening to the music at the credits and felt the urge straight away to share how much I loved this story all the way to the end. To be honest I expected the last two movies to have gone downhill as happens most often with producers losing it to dish up something even more exiting than the last box office success. And sure, there was some of that action but especially the ending was very very good .. Unpredictable and true to the character of the Mocking Jay: Fierce yet fragile and genuine, which makes up her strength. Plus the music at the end pleased me entirely. I will give this a ten just for being made so true and gentle and patient enough to show some emotion, where we're usually treated with shallow jokes, punchlines, flashcards and sensation to produce a forced smile on our numb faces. Anything to avoid genuine feelings it seems at times, quick .. make a joke! Never thought I would but I loved it .. splendid. The imagery was stunning and the details, such as the designs of the Capitol buildings very well done and reminiscent of ominous and grandiose communist regimes as we still know them around the world. I was surprised the last two movies received a slightly lower rating, they certainly did not disappoint. There's a valuable lesson about what society should do once they spot a psychopath in power .. end it on the spot, so we can all enjoy our lives in peace

title: To bad
text: Would have loved it to be better. But it is not. Storyline with holes in it bigger then a division 5 football team defence.

title: Slow
text: The core ideas are interesting and compelling but it is so drawn out and boring that it's hard to care. The engaging and interesting characters no longer carry the film. Whilst it does take you to a satisfying conclusion to the story it just takes too long to get there. The effects are good. The music, the acting, everything about it is good except the pacing. I wish they did an alternate version for people like me that had the first film the same but then combined the next three films into two to make a really entertaining trilogy rather than a meandering quadrilogy. Well there you go, all of them watched!

title: A bad ending, compared to the other films.
text: This film is the fourth and final adaptation of the literary trilogy by Suzanne Collins, and brings to the cinema the second half of the last book. I didn't read them, I have no particular intention of doing so for any particular reason, so I will ignore the books and focus on the film.In this film, Katniss decides to go beyond what is asked of her by the Resistance. They wanted a mascot, someone to pose and advertise their cause. She decides to take the initiative, be at the front and take part in the decisive battle for control of the Capital. She wants to kill Snow. On the other hand, she fears Peeta's mental health, after he has been rescued from the hands of the dictator. After all, he still suffers with the marks of torture and deep brainwashing he suffered.It is difficult to describe what I felt when I finished watching this film. This tetralogy was one of the most tasty and interesting that I have seen in cinema in many years. Loaded with an epic sense, a sweet scent of adventure, good action scenes and touches of social criticism, the story is very good and definitely worth it. All three previous films were able to take advantage of this and give us the best. It is true that the previous film did not seem so good, but I did not expect the disaster that this film came to be! Compared to the others, it seems made by amateurs and confirms that the idea of dividing the final book into two films was terrible. This film simply had little to tell us other than the final assault on the Capital, which should have been the final and culminating half of a third and final film. But pulling money out of the public and making them pay sounds better, and the movie industry has to bill, so let's make two films for the silly viewers to pay a little more and the studio to make a few extra million dollars.The cast remained at the same level as the previous films. If this film failed, it was not the actors' fault, but the director, Francis Lawrence. Jennifer Lawrence has remained excellent, but does not bring anything new. Katniss continues to look hot in war and cold in love. Donald Sutherland was excellent, although he went a little too far in his madness and seems to be really crazy in some scenes. Julianne Moore, who gave life to President Coin, turns out to be a pleasant surprise in that she is not quite what she appears, but this turnaround was to be expected by the way the film prepared it. Josh Hutcherson continues to do a decent job, but not pleasant to me. All the other actors, who had more or less opportunities to give an air of value and talent in the previous films, practically disappear.The film is loaded with scenes of a lot of action, explosions and shots. If everything seems real, thanks to excellent sound effects and first-rate CGI, the same cannot be said of all the costumes. Peacekeepers, for example, look like Star Wars imperial soldiers. A careful cinematography with good contrast, excellent sets and very realistic fights, along with an excellent soundtrack, complete the production values.A lot of action, explosions and shots, good actors doing the best they know, but without material to work on a film that has very little story to tell... this is how we can sum up this film, which was certainly a disappointment for many who they had enjoyed the previous films.

title: Watch this on fast forward.

title: What happens after the end?
text: Which is the goal? What happens to characters after the end? To critique a story, not only we must see the words written, but also those meant, what happens between the scenes, or after the end. We a dystopia, criticizing modern issues of course, and not the future, as any dystopia or eutopia (and not utopia). And we see a hero! As always. What about the rest of people living there? And how more sexist can it get (meant spoiler), the ending? The hero -and a few more characters- can do a big success , like a revolution. But what about the rest? We can't all be big success, otherwise no one would be. This is a competitive view on society, and most stories are based on this, as well as a "villain" who makes the protagonist "the good guy" for no apparent reason: they good guys don't seem to make any big choices: they were just born in this world and (violently) fight for their lives. It also glorifies violence to some extent. And how can a story (action or not) be without all these? It can, and I have read it. The book "Political thinking for the masses: way to freedom" talks about life, how we can be without all these (hatred, violence, demonization, sexism).

title: could be much better
text: Disliked it, and for good reason. The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015) left me yearning for the spark that ignited the franchise. While the acting maintained a baseline competence, it lacked the emotional depth needed to truly engage the audience. The film editing felt disjointed, with scenes dragging on unnecessarily, and the pacing stumbling like a wounded tribute. The strength of the series, once a beacon of dystopian storytelling, flickered dimly in this installment, overshadowed by a weak and predictable plot. The music, a potential lifeline, failed to elevate the viewing experience, becoming a mere background hum. Cinematography, once a standout, fell into the shadows, offering little to salvage the visual journey. The message, while present, felt diluted and lost amidst the mediocre execution. Mockingjay - Part 2, sadly, became a forgettable finale to a once-promising saga.

title: know who the real enemy is
text: I saw the first two movies in the franchise right after they came out. I didn't get around to seeing parts three and four until this year when I heard that there's a prequel coming out soon. From what I could tell, the last movie reminded the viewer that you can't appeal to your oppressor's morality. And now "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2" features a scene where Katniss reminds her compatriots who the enemy is. This could apply to any situation where those in power try to turn the people against each other to stay in power (divide and rule, as it's known). Sometimes it does take one person to call out the lies.Anyway, it's not a masterpiece, but still a worthy end to the series. I'll be eager to see the prequel.

title: Why the extra film? I can't but think it was to fleece the public.
text: The final film in the Hunger Games series of films. Mockingjay was made into two films. Why? Originally intended as a trilogy like the book series it is based on I left the viewing feeling that the film studio have fleeced the public into seeing an extra film. I would only recommend seeing this entry after reviewing Mockingjay part one.It is difficult to view as a standalone entry. It is more of the same rebel fight against the Capitol evil that you saw in that entry. The cast make a good effort in their roles in particular Jennifer Lawrence as heroine Katniss Everdeen. The late Philip Seymour Hoffman reprises his role as the curiously named Plutarch Heavensbee in scenes filmed just prior to his untimely death.Other questions still remain such as the curious love triangle between Everdeen and her childhood sweetheart Gale Hawthorne (Liam Hemsworth) and Peeta Melark (Josh Hutcherson). The film suffers from sequel syndrome and CGI overload in some sequences. Other great actors such as Jeffrey Wright as Beetee seem under utilised. All in all I would only recommend this film for TV or DVD viewing.

title: cramming 35 minutes into 109 minutes
text: In a bizarre twist of Amazon, I watched the first and third installments, then the second, and then the final. I probably have a unique perspective, not unlike the time I watched the Pelican Brief in a theater that was halfway through the 3rd reel before the manager realized the projectionist had failed to show the 2nd reel. Nonetheless, I was able to buy into the overall story-line, and had appropriate ambivalence about most of the characters. Of course, my loyalty to Katnip never wavered, even though it occurred to me that she was considerably more brave than intelligent, and more lucky than skilled. Still and all, by the final nearly eternal 45 minutes of this, the conclusion, I was absolutely frantic with impatience. I didn't care what ANYONE did, whether a hero turned evil, or a villain turned good. I was far beyond deep thought, reflection, analysis, or....and then it hit me - this is how they ended Game of Thrones, with a massive and transparent abuse of a loyal fanbase. Golly, Hollywood, even when you succeed, you find a way to fail.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2
text: There's not very much to say about this film, or indeed the trilogy. Of four films. Get your head around that in your own time.It turned a set of Young Adult books into films. People who liked those books went and saw those films.They probably enjoyed them too.It made a star out of Jennifer Lawrence. So that's...something.Are they any good though? No. Is this film so much better than the others? No.It's run of the mill tween fantasy/distopian stuff, which will be a cultural hit for a while and then vanish off the face of the Earth.Much like 'Divergent' and 'Twilight'.I say this rather hopefully.

title: Still hungry for more
text: The official title of this movie is so long that I prefer to use the abbreviation "HG3B". It is the fourth and final film in the transposition to the big screen of Suzanne Collins' trilogy of young adult novels - the last book has been turned into two movies - which I read years before the films started to appear. HG3B" picks up exactly where "HG3A" ended, with the leader of the rebellion by the 13 Districts against the controlling Capitol at the evil heart of Panem, the archer Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), recovering from an attempt to strangle her by a brainwashed Peeta (Josh Hutcherson). As always, Lawrenece is terrific and, as her character has developed in the films, so in real life her acting career has been "Catching Fire". Hutcherson is better in this final segment as he has a more complicated character to portray. And Donald Sutherland and Julianne Moorre are both icily convincing as the presidents of Panem and the rebellion respectively. The late Philip Seymour Hoffman makes brief appearances, since the two "Mockingjay" films were shot back-to-back while he was still alive. .This fourth movie is the darkest of them all - both literally (especially when the action goes underground) and metaphorically (when Katniss finds that she had been increasingly manipulated by those whom she ought to have been able to trust). There are no Hunger Games as such in the final novel of the trilogy but, in this last film, effectively Panem itself has become one gigantic Hunger Games as Katniss and her combat unit have to battle all sorts of mortal challenges in the form of pods and mutts. Unlike a superhero blockbuster movie, there is no long-running final battle in which good clearly triumphs over evil; instead Katniss struggles through a whole series of physical and moral challenges that result in a serious blurring of the line between good and evil. Katniss has to make some choices, both on the battlefield and in her love life, and in each case she does what she knows to be right.This has been a satisfying franchise that has stayed faithful to the original novels throughout. The original source material told a compelling story and Collins ensured that the movies stayed true to that story. Francis Lawrence did an excellent job on the last three of the four films. Above all, the central role was perfectly cast. We may now seen the end of the Mockingjay (although there is talk of both a prequel and a sequel from Collins), but assuredly we have only just seen the beginning of the glittering career of the talented Jennifer Lawrence.

title: The Life Of A VIctor...
text: It wasn't the movie that I had expected but had a satisfiable conclusion.Alright with a start rough around the edges and an ending that was good. The writing was a bit dull. There were some repetetive elements that were getting quiet annoying. They could have made this into a single movie instead of dragging it and making it into 2 parts for $$$. The characters were fine also. Peeta's character was a bit confusing though and the characters that died barely mattered for the audience as they did a pretty bad job on adding character depth other than for Katniss.The visuals were pretty good, especially the action scenes. The music was also veru good, the use of the instruments and the vocals.A disappointing movie, the worst out of the 4 hunger game movies.Memorable: No Rewatchable: No

title: An exciting, poignant, and overall satisfying conclusion.
text: With the unflinchingly grim Mockingjay Part 2, The Hunger Games comes to an exciting, poignant, and overall satisfying conclusion.

title: The book was better
text: And that's saying something, because the film is pretty neat. It does it flaws, as this series did, but watching this having mostly forgotten the books, I think it recreated a lot of what I liked about this book well.It still struggles to express a lot of the nuances and power the book's scenes had, but it did the visuals of the book a degree of justice.Truthfully, I think I would have preferred if the films leaned more into writing around and modifying the plot of the books. Minor things were tweaked - A character here, a scene there, but the broad strokes are the same. A seven or an eight is about what I'd give the book.

title: not as powerful a showing as it could be
text: Picking up right where the previous installment left off, this final Hunger Games entry (unless they concoct a spinoff or superfluous sequel) is a tactical battle to end all battles as Katniss and the remaining rebels attempt to infiltrate the Capitol and overthrow the tyrannical President Snow, an inherently difficult mission but even more so as they justifiably question the importance and sacrifice of what needs to be done. With several key players returning to the fray this delivers what's expected, though at times it's much darker than you'd think, but the story lags, the third act is much too drawn-out, and the conclusion doesn't have enough impact to make this an epic-scale finale. Its reach may have exceeded its grasp, but it still has entertainment value thanks to a stellar cast of actors. **½
